title: 111_s451
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Girl Scouts USA Centennial Commemorative Coin Act". The Girl Scouts of the United States of America is the world's preeminent organization dedicated solely to girls, founded by Juliette Gordon Low in 1912. With the help of Sir Robert Baden-Powell, Low organized the first 2 Girl Scout Troops in Savannah, Georgia. She devoted 15 years of her life to building the organization, drafting the Girl Scout laws and making it the largest voluntary association for women and girls in the United States. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America was chartered by the United States Congress in 1950. Today, there are over 3.7 million members in 236,000 troops across the US and territories. The organization is part of a global family of 10 million girls and adults in 145 countries. Over 50 million American women have enjoyed Girl Scouting during their childhood. The Girl Scouts of the United States of America celebrates its 100th Anniversary on March 12, 2012, continuing to inspire, challenge, and empower girls everywhere. SEC. 3. COIN SPECIFICATIONS.

The Secretary of the Treasury will mint and issue up to 350,000 $1 silver coins commemorating the centennial of the Girl Scouts of the USA. Each coin will weigh 26.73 grams, have a diameter of 1.500 inches, and contain 90% silver and 10% copper. The coins will be legal tender and considered numismatic items.

SEC. 4. DESIGN OF COINS. The design of the coins minted under this Act for the centennial of the Girl Scouts of the USA will include specific inscriptions and symbols. The design will be selected by the Secretary in consultation with relevant organizations and committees. SEC. 5. ISSUANCE OF COINS. Coins minted under this Act shall be issued in uncirculated and proof qualities at the United States Mint at West Point, New York. The Secretary may issue coins only during the calendar year beginning on January 1, 2011. SEC. 6. SALE OF COINS. The coins issued under this Act will be sold by the Secretary at a price equal to the face value, surcharge, and cost of designing and issuing the coins. Bulk sales will be offered at a discount, and prepaid orders will be accepted at a reasonable discount. SEC. 7. SURCHARGES.

All sales of coins issued under this Act shall include a $10 surcharge per coin. The surcharges received will be paid to the Girl Scouts of the United States of America for program development. The Comptroller General of the United States will audit the Girl Scouts' expenditures related to these funds.
